author: p0W3RH311
body:
Hi Guys !

in PS we can use $Matches to see the matches. its awesome to add 2 new variable to see the pre-match match and the post-match. example:

```
PS C:\> 'powershell' -match 's'
True
PS C:\> $Matches

Name                           Value
----                           -----
0                              s

PS C:\> $PreMatch
power
PS C:\> $PostMatch
hell
```

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
It's not entirely clear what the profit is?
```
 > 'powershell' -match '^(.+)(s)(.+)$'
True
 > $matches

Name                           Value
----                           -----
3                              hell
2                              s
1                              power
0                              powershell

 > 'powershell' -split '(?<=^.+)(s)(?=.+$)'
power
s
hell
```

comments.author: p0W3RH311
comments.body:
@237dmitry 

thanks 

yes i know we can use regex for this and also we can use maybe psbreakpoint to create this variables prematch and postmatch in global scope.

but the benefit to $prematch and $postmatch is like $matches. we can use these variables outside the context of regex like $matches

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
As @237dmitry demonstrated, it's pretty trivial to retrieve these values when necessary.

I'm not sure I see the benefit of having pwsh _always_ spend extra cycles performing additional operations to retrieve these values when not even asked to do so.
